awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Insect bioremediation and biodegradation for solid waste
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a cheaper alternative waste management strategy reducing greenhouse gas emissions as required for compliance with rapidly changing environmental policies. This insect-based treatment process can help waste managers to address emerging contaminants of concern that would conventionally require costly treatment additions and/or renovations to meet upcoming regulatory standards. Processing recovered products from insect biomass can mineralize bioaccumulative and persistent chemicals, e.g.,  diesel engine combustion byproducts. This method of organic waste treatment can be integrated into mainstream waste treatment trains. While there are direct public benefits, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions, this technology may also be used to test the feasibility of using derived insect lipids as an alternative biofuel source, resulting in economic benefits. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology to change the way organic waste is managed by streamlining biological treatment for decontamination and byproduct recovery. The treatment train utilizes the Quantitative Structure Activity Relationship (QSAR) model and nontarget/suspect-screening analysis techniques to identify contaminant profiles while employing insects to reduce organic waste, recover nutrients (e.g., protein fractions), and sequester organic contaminants. Post production treatment for insect tissue ensures downstream production of high-quality protein feed and renewable biodiesel. This approach in low-cost waste reduction utilizes insect larvae to efficiently process organic waste by feeding on it as a substrate. The resulting insect biomass has been shown to sequester harmful contaminants. The end-products from these processes are: 1) insect lipids, the input material for renewable diesel production, and 2) low-chemical risk protein powder, which is enriched with growth-limiting amino acids for animal feed (i.e., chicken and fish), and 3) organic contaminant treatment, which can off-set the cost of organic waste treatment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

Black Soldier Fly Larvae (BSFL) offer significant potential as a sustainable protein source due to their high feed conversion efficiency and rapid growth. However, high production costs and market challenges have hindered industry profitability. The Bioremedi team participated in the NSF I-Corps program and conducted a broad range of interviews for customer discovery and business model validation to find a market fit for BSFL reared on urban pre-consumer foodwaste. The Bioremedi team is led by Wenting Li and Olivia Wrightwood, co- Entrepreneurial leads with Heather Bischel (PI), Camille Wolf (Technical Lead), and Phil Li (Industrial mentor). We present a breakdown customer discovery interviews by segment in Figure 1. The main outcomes of this project are that we:

  1. Confirmed target customers,
  2. Revised the business model,
  3. Formed a startup, Inzyt Engineering LLC (registered in California on Jan 13, 2023),
  4. Constructed our first bioreactor prototype,
  5. Received recommendation for the NSF STTR phase 1 proposal and submitted an application.

Target customers

Our Bioremedi team participated in the National NSF I-CORPS program following participation in the Bay Area regional I-CORPS. We identified pet owners and pet food manufacturers as potential customers. We hypothesized that environmental concerns would drive consumers toward insect-based pet food. Our customer interviews revealed that pet health issues, specifically skin and gastrointestinal problems, were the primary factors influencing purchasing decisions. Veterinarians play a crucial role in recommending specialty diets, especially veterinary-specific brands. Our target customers are dog owners seeking hypoallergenic, affordable, and health-supporting dog food options. To address these needs, we propose BSFL protein enriched with antimicrobial peptides (AMP) as a premium ingredient. Below we summarize Bioremedi’s customer discovery and market research.

We validated customer pain points of the primary customers, dog owners, identifying a need for:

  • Cheaper alternative to prescription or specialty dog foods,
  • Hypoallergenic protein replacement,
  • Dietary immunological support.

We determined the potential value proposition of premium AMP-enriched BSFL dog food products offered by Inzyt’s technology to be:

  • Enhanced BSFL protein product for dog health,
  • Lower risk of food-borne pathogen outbreaks (e.g., Salmonella),
  • Cheaper alternative to prescription or other premium/specialty dog foods.

Additionally, through the interviews of potential key partners and other current industry members, we identified the key obstacles to adoption of BSFL protein in dog food to be:

  • High production costs render BSFL-based dog food more expensive than conventional dog food,
  • Unfamiliarity with insects in food products, especially in North America,
  • The economic and physical infrastructure has not yet been established to allow for scalability in the insect protein market.

Business model

During the I-CORPS program, we diagramed our business ecosystem with corresponding key players. We developed a decentralized business model that leverages local goods and services through a series of modules, containing up to 20 treatment nodes and one homogenization system. We evaluated the diagram with interviews and letters of support from partners and influencers. We also built out preliminary cash flow estimates from information gathered during customer discovery conducted to date.

Start-up Formation 

The team registered a startup, Inzyt Engineering LLC (Inzyt), in California. The two co-Entrepreneur Leads (ELs) are the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and Chief Technology Officer (CTO). Inzyt is participating Tech Futures Group in Northern California for grant application assistance. The team also applied for a NSF Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) grant.

Prototype

Inzyt designed and built their first semi-automatic bioreactor pilot-scale bioreactor in 2023 within the context of the NSF I-CORPS program (Figure 2). The bioreactor is located at the Renewable Energy Anaerobic Digester (READ) facility at UC Davis facility. We conducted one substrate rearing experiment (21-day) in which we reared  10,000 BSFL on either pre-treated brewery spent grain (BSG) or on residual solids from a foodwaste anaerobic digestion treatment train (T3). The BSFL showed similar survival rate (>90%) with both diets. A Our analysis of antimicrobial peptide (AMPs) in BSFL larvae revealed high AMP production when T3 solids were used as substrate. This unexpected result motivated us to further develop AMP-enriched BSFL as Inzyt’s premium product. Among 16 antimicrobial peptides, BSFL reared on T3 residual solids displayed an 89.6% total production increase of four major AMPs compared to those raised on pretreated BSG. This potential to enhance pet food's health benefits aligns with the specific needs of our target customers.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2024
Modified by: Heather N Bischel

Images (1 of )
  • The picture of pilot-scale bioreactor constructed using I-CORPS R&D development fund.
    Wenting Li
    Creative Commons
    Heather N Bischel
    Figure 2
  • Breakdown of customer discovery interviews by segment.
    Wenting Li
    Creative Commons
    Heather N Bischel
